name: Matt
comment info: Data can be misleading without proper context, including countries included in migration, region population / percent of population, etc.

name: Karla Cantú
comment info: I think that this graph shows the intra and inter migration around the world.

name: S. Rose
comment info: Seems like the graph shows intra- and intercontinental migration with the exceptions that (1) Oceania is quite reasonably used to combined New Zealand and Australia, and (2) Mexico is shown as part of Latin America. That seems like a controversial choice, as it's purely an ethnic rather than geographical distinction.

name: Isaac
comment info: The cost of natural disasters has gone up dramatically. In 2005, Hurricane Katrina cost $161billion, and in 2017, natural disasters cost $283 billion.

name: Shoup
comment info: My students wondered if the 'within-land mass' migrations must be country to country within that land mass, as opposed to, say, from state to state or city to city within 1 country.

name: Francely Ortiz
comment info: I noticed that the most migrations happen from South America to North America. We also noticed  that  asia has the biggest migration. We wonder why  oceania have such low population.

name: Trinity & Leo
comment info: We have noticed that Asia has a high immigration rate, Asians mostly move to North American and Europe. A headline for this graph "Migration in the continents" and the graphs story is showing migration all over and how it people migrate and the diffrent rates in each continents.

name: Sharidy, Esmeralda, Starlyn
comment info: This graph represents the amount of people moving out from their country, as is noticed Asia besides is the biggest continent is receiving the more amount of people, overall from all countries people are migrating but Asia is the one receiving  more.

name: Sanniya Blake
comment info: What we noticed was the arrows showing migration to North America and Europe. We also noticed that the arrows going in a circle gets skinnier the less the number is. We wonder why there's so much migration to North America and Europe. We also wondered what the arrows going in the circle represent. We think it is showing the population and the number of immigrants coming to each continent.

name: Pariz, Ada mari, Chris
comment info: I noticed that most people are migrating throughout asia. As some years went by Asia was being filled with all of the other continents. Most of the population is coming and going from continent to continent but the cirlces are the ones that are staying there such as europe and asia filling with people. many people are not staying in the other continets. MOst people are leaving oceaia and not going back.

name: Mourien Lansiquot
comment info: I have noticed that Asia has the most people migrating all throughout Asia. Also, why does Asia have such a thick migration? Another thing also because of the lack of profitable economics, opportunities and abilities.

name: Rodrigo
comment info: The graph doesn't use relative frequencies, which makes larger continents appear to have larger migration.  This data is meaningful because it shows a lot of people moving away from their own country.

name: nayely
comment info: Over the years the Asian population was filling with European, North American, African and Latin American emigrants. millions of people emigrate in the Asian continent

name: Yaen Torres Mitchell
comment info: One of the biggest things that we could depict from the graph is that the biggest immigration flow is from South America to North America, which equaled 26.4 million in 2017. One of the things that our group wondered is how the data from this graph was collected. Also, our group would give this graph the headline of "Immigration and Migration flow in the world".

name: Lukas
comment info: i wondered what it was that was migrating.

name: Taevyon
comment info: I think his is cool graph showing all the moment we had wit all the immigration

name: Easton Vander Stoep
comment info: What I though was pretty weird was the amount of people moving in their own country. There's more people moving within their own country than people moving to other countries. I would like to know where they got their data from, see how they know all of this. But, still a pretty cool map showing where people are migrating to.

name: stats 04
comment info: Our group noticed many people go to North America but, not many people leave North America.

name: Matt
comment info: Is the migration in Oceania strictly humans, or is it partially emus?

name: Bob
comment info: Not many people go to Oceania and the majority of people that migrate in their own continent is Asia.

name: Cally,Niya, Emily, Sabrina
comment info: Why do you think most people are migrating to their same continent in such big volume like in Asia?

name: C. Allmann
comment info: Asia has more migration within it's continent as it has the largest arrow. I also noticed that migration to North America is larger to the West Coast rather than to the East Coast where throughout history we have seen the highest numbers of migration to New York until when we started migration west. It's interesting to see how we have kept that pattern after so many years.

name: Jackrabbit
comment info: i wonder why so many people are staying in their own country

name: Sammie and statistics team mates
comment info: Our catchy title is...The Worlds Migration Hotspots! :)

name: Alec Schlote
comment info: It is very interesting at the amount of people that migrated among their own countries. Especially Europe and Asia. However, I would like to know how they are finding their data.

name: Phil
comment info: Our title is "An interesting view of immigration"

name: matt
comment info: I noticed that Asia has a lot of migration but Australia has almost none. I wonder if it is because people feel safe in Australia but not in other country.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @matt, is the migration strictly humans though?

replies.name: P
replies.comment info: @matt haha nice ;)

name: G. Avlonitis
comment info: I wonder what qualifies as internal migration.  Moving more than a certain distance?  Moving for certain reasons?

name: Jane
comment info: I notice that the graph seems to depict the migration of people between different continents. It is interesting to see where people travel to and from. I wonder if the amount of people migrating within Asia and Europe is because of the dense population or because of other factors (political or social reasons to move). I am also curious as to what the purpose of the graph is/what its use in 2017 was. Was the graph created to depict migration tendencies in political conferences (maybe United Nations)?. My headline would be: 365 Days of Human Migration.

name: Moderator Corey
comment info:
Have you ever seen a map that is called a graph?  Here is one that makes showing migration within and between continents easy to comprehend.  You wondered about several aspects of the graph.  Was this the migration of people or animals?  Did people migrate only in one direction in their continent?  Why were there no numbers on the dashed lines?  What’s going on in Asia?

You had many catchy headlines including Katie of Eden Prairie, MN whose headline had a double entendre "Migration in Millions: How the World Moves".  Good noticing and wondering leads to snappy headlines.

Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Talk to your classmates and read the moderators’ replies. Dig deeper into what the graph shows.  Perhaps you will find more things to notice, wonder, claim or conjecture. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, September 13 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graph, and two Stat Nuggets. And join us next Wednesday, September 19 for the next "What's Going On In This Graph?".  I think it might possibly have to do with fast food restaurants, unless we have a Hurricane Florence graph.  Signing off -- Sharon in Boston, where 27% of the population is foreign-born, and Corey Andreasen in Qatar, where 88% of the population is foreign-born. Visit the "What's Going On In This Graph?" archives to keep responding. Hope to see you next week.

name: Day
comment info: I wonder how internal migration can be correlated to unrest. It is not complete because europe has a exceedingly high internal unrest rate.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Day. Can you say more about what you mean by "not complete?" What is missing from the graph that you would like to see clarified?

name: LO
comment info: I am fascinated by how many of the comments are North America- centric. Many observations are about how many people are migrating to/from North America. Really speaks to our mentality as a developed nation..

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Thanks for joining the conversation, @LO. I was expecting you to notice something about the graph. But you noticed something about the comments! Is there anything you wonder? About either the graph or the comments?

name: Ethan
comment info: Not many people going in and out of Oceania.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: @Ethan Maybe most people don't leave Oceania because they feel safe there?

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Ethan that's Australia for you

name: Michael Michaelson
comment info: I notice that much of the Middle East is included in Asia. I wonder if this is part of the reason behind the large level of migration within Asia. I also wonder if the migration within Asia is due to the large population within the continent.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Michael Michaelson. Yes, the Middle East is part of Asia. (That's where I am right now!) The number of countries between which to move, and the population of Asia might both be reasons for the large level. Can you think of any other possible reasons?

name: Carter
comment info: The arrows pointing back at the nation could be that people are migrating within their continent.

name: Alex
comment info: I wonder if the amount of people migrating within Asia is more influenced by the population of  Asia or the countries they included in Asia.

name: David
comment info: I wonder if the great amount of migration in Asia and Europe may be a function of  their populations.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @David. What could they have done with the graph to answer that question?

name: Bob Kennedy
comment info:
Whats up!!!!
This graph seems to talk about how much people immigrate to places especially the U.S being the most targeted place to go to & Europe being the second. I also see that Europe & Asia has the most populated continent/ immigration.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Bob Kennedy! You've noticed some big things in the graph. What else do you see? What do you wish was there that isn't?

name: bill
comment info: people move a lot

name: Anthony
comment info: It looks like it's showing how many millions of people are moving around the continents.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Anthony. What did you notice in the graph that tells you this? Did you notice anything more about this graph? What do you wonder that the graph may not be telling you?

name: Olivia
comment info: This is about the migration of people from all the continents

name: Emily
comment info: It is about migration to and from different countries

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Emily. What do you notice about the way people migrate? Any patterns? Anything you wonder about that the graph doesn't tell you?

name: Maddy
comment info: This is about the migration to and from different countries/continents. But I have noticed that there are hardly any North American immigrants but many people are moving to North America.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hello, @Maddy. I see a few Ohio responses. Are you classmates? You pointed out something that you noticed. Is there anything that you wonder about? Why do you think more are moving to North America than from?

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Maddy That is a very good statement I also wonder why Asia has more people migrating into itself

name: Will
comment info: I think the graph is showing how Pangaea split into the 7 continents. Each continent shows a degree of rotation, of how it turned. And just now I see the title. Hopefully its just to confuse people

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Will. Titles are a great clue to what a graph represents! Now that you've seen the title, what do you think the graph represents? What do you notice?

name: Claire
comment info: It seems to be a chart of however many immigrants travel to America in 2017 with their original country and language.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Thanks for responding, @Claire. What do you notice that leads you to think it's about immigrants traveling to America? How do you see the original country and language? What is your snappy title?

name: Molly
comment info: I noticed a lot of arrows going to Europe and North America. I think this graph shows the migration of either birds or people (in millions) in 2017.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Molly. Thanks for responding. What do you know about the movement of birds and those of people that might help you decide which is represented in the map?

replies.name: E
replies.comment info: @Molly Good observation, we noticed that too

name: Jackson
comment info: hello i think this is a graph of how many immigrants come to each place

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Jackson. Is there anything else you notice in the graph? Anything you wonder about?

name: haley
comment info: i think it is about immagrants

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @haley, what do you notice that makes you say that? What do you think it tells us about immigrants?

name: Ryan
comment info: I noticed a lot of arrows going towards the U.S. I think it is a map of immigration routes from 2017

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Ryan. What other general patterns do you notice about immigration routes?

name: Blake
comment info: What I wonder most about this is, How large are the populations of immigrants from unknown origins? Are they too insignificant to display (which would be odd, since they were deemed significant enough to warrant a note)? Have they gone uncounted? Hmmm...

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Blake. That's an interesting question. I wonder how many immigrants are from unknown origins. Countries generally don't allow immigrants without knowing a background.

name: Mitchell
comment info: I found it interesting Mexico as a part of South America as it typically appears as a part of North America on many maps. I wonder what made the map makers decide to group Mexico with South America?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @Mitchell. Yes, that is interesting. Although I think one clue can be found in what I noticed. They didn't call it South America, they called it Latin America. I wonder why they made the choice to distinguish it that way.

name: Mrs. Brosi
comment info: My 5th grade students debated whether or not this graph depicts humans or animals. Many also took the circles literally to mean that was the path of migration in that continent (for example migration from the western part of Africa to the eastern part). They wondered if and when the people or animals migrate back.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Mrs. Brosi class.

You wonder what is migrating – people or animals.  The graph does not tell you, but thinking about the graph, what is your conjecture and why?  The Reveal, which will be posted by Friday, will give you the original article and you can read the answer.

I see that you noted that there is a directed arrow.  This would imply that migration within a continent went in one direction, for example, you said from western part of Africa to the eastern part.  You wondered what happened to the migration in the other direction.  Could this be the “net migration”, for example, western Africa minus eastern Africa?  Or, maybe there is another explanation.  Maybe there should be an arrow at both ends of the line.  I think you are onto something.

name: NR/AB
comment info:
We noticed that the width of the arrows correlate with the amount of migration. There are arrows inclosing continents which would most likely describe migration within the continent, while the cross-continental arrows highlight migration amongst continents.
We wonder for what reason this graph was created by the United Nations--whether it was just a recap of 2017 migration or if it's being used to project future patterns. We're also curious as to the math behind the orientation of the continents and arrows.
Our headline would be: Around the World in 365 Days

name: Bella and Nick
comment info:
It is interesting that many people are moving to North America and Europe, and a lot of people are migrating within Asia. It is also interesting that few people are immigrating to Africa and Oceania. I wonder if people are moving to places based on distance and the development of the continent.
Catchy headline: Lit Migration

name: Tyson Stritesky
comment info:
I notice...
North America has the most influx of migration. 

I wonder...
What is the cause of these movements? 

Headline...
Birds or Boats? The Story of Migration

replies.name: S
replies.comment info:
@Tyson Stritesky
I like your headline! We were also wondering why there is so much migration within continents?

name: Dingoes
comment info: What we found most interesting is how the largest out of continent migration trend was from South America/Latin America to North America.  What is causing that?

name: Alec
comment info: Interesting how there is a lot of immigration internally in the european continent, even more so for Asia. I wonder where the immigrants are mainly moving from in Oceania. I think a lot--or at least some--of immigrants that are moving internally in Europe are balkans moving to countries like Germany, France, etc.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Alec that is a very interesting thought. What do you think about the immigration in Asia? I feel that the current economic trends in China, India, and the Middle East likely play a very large role in these movements.

name: Karmen
comment info:
1.	We notice that the arrow thickness and size reveals the number of migrations.  The arrows that wind back represent migration in the continent.  The most frequent migration patterns out of continent is to North America and Europe.  The most frequent migration within the same continent is in Asia.
2.	We wonder what is migrating, people or an animal?  What factors lead to the migration patterns that are shown.  Are there any factors that influence certain arrows?
3.	Migration between continents.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @Karmen --
You wonder what is migrating – people or animals.  The graph does not tell you, but thinking about the graph, what is your conjecture and why?  Let us know what you and your classmates have decided.  The Reveal, that will be posted by Friday, will give you the original article and you will see the answer.

name: ZN
comment info: A greater percentage of people are migrating internationally to North America and Europe from Asia and Latin America. The larger percentage of people in Asia and Europe migrate within their own continent. I wonder why so may people migrate within their own continents (Asia and Europe)? If I was to make a catchy title, it would be "A World on the Move."

name: Matt and Allie
comment info: We noticed that there are lots of people migration with in both Asia and Europe. Also, we were wondering why they are so few people moving both to and from Oceania. If we had to title this piece we would call it "Connecting the word"

name: CM
comment info: Most migration occurs within continents or to North America or Europe.  Why is it that so few people are migrating within North America?  A headline could be: "Why Are Europe and North America So Hot? Migration Patterns Explain.

name: C
comment info:
I notice that not many people are emigrating America compared to immigrating.  I also notice that not many people are coming into Oceania or leaving it for that matter. I wonder why, isn't Australia a hub for job opportunities.
No Immigration or Emigration in Outback Steak House

name: Lauren
comment info: I notice that the thicker the lines the more people are migrating. I wonder why whoever made this map decided to set up the world that way. A snappy headline that would go with this is "Migration among the Nations".

name: KW
comment info: Hey Sharon you are a delightful young moderator.

name: Greta T.
comment info: What constitutes a "migrant" in this context and how are they determining the total number of them?

name: JW
comment info: This graph is super intriguing however, I wondering what percentage of people migrated to a different part of the continent which they resided on?

replies.comment info:
HI, @JW--
Take another look at the graph.  Maybe talk to your classmates.  You will find the answer to your question.

name: adam
comment info: is this about people or birds

replies.comment info:
Hi, @adam --
Good wonder.  What do you think?  What evidence in the graph leads you to this conclusion?

name: Georgia
comment info: is this graph talking about birds or animals

name: Gi
comment info:
The Graph is about immigration. The graph shows how countless people move from their Country to another Country. I wonder why many people move to North America? Is this about more opportunities? Improve your financial life?Is North America the best choice to live in?
In my opinion is a great place to live.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Gi--

You say that “countless people move from country to country”.  But, somehow these migration totals have been determined.  How do you think they were determined?

name: Anne
comment info: I noticed that a lot of immgration has been happening these days. I wonder the world gets closer. One interesting thing I found in this graph is that many people has been moving to Greenland. Which factor is dragging people there?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Anne

What makes you think that a lot of people are moving to Greenland? I think you are suspect of this.  Could the graph mean something else?

name: Simone Siqueira Maia
comment info: Very interesting graph about imigration around the world. The most interesting part for me is the imigration from Asia to Greenland...because the Greenland is a important productor of fish and it is interesting to market or business in Ásia. So very interesting! !!!++

name: Jay
comment info:
What I noticed was there are a lot of people who move to North America.
What I wonder is why A lot of people immigrate into North America.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, Jay. What hypotheses can you and others come up with why there are so many people migrating to North America?
Do you have a catchy headline for the graph?

name: Atul wadhwani
comment info: Hello my name is Atul Wadhwani and i'm an esl student at ccb school. The graph looks like it's  about the immigration system showing  how many people are moving from their country to other countries. The funny thing is it looks like many people are moving to United states.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, Atul.  Thank you for your response.
There are many people who are migrating from one continent to another.  I wonder how many there were in 2017.  Can you calculate the number?

But others migrate within their continent.  I wonder how many people did not leave their continent, but migrated within it.  

I wonder, which is greater in 2017 – migrating between continents or within continents?

name: Ellesa and Ava
comment info:
We noticed that there is a lot more people moving into North America than are moving out. Also, Europe and Asia have a lot of people moving within the continent.
We were curious why there were such large numbers of people migrating within Asia.
A good title would be Mass Migration: People Really Don't Like Where They Live.

name: Henry
comment info:
In this graph, I noticed how there were relatively no North Americans who migrated to other continents.

I wonder how the graph would differ if it were based off of relative frequencies, rather than frequencies. It would be interesting to see the difference that Asia has due to the large population. 

Snappy headline
2017 Migration

replies.comment info:
Henry, you bring up relative frequencies.
I wonder if you mean the proportion of migration to the continent’s population?  How could you easily find the data to calculate these proportions?  How about doing it and sharing your findings?
You are definitely onto something here.  Maybe this insight could be in your snappy headline.

@Henry,  you bring up relative frequencies.  I wonder if you mean the proportion of migration to the continent’s population?  How could you easily find the data to calculate these proportions?  How about doing it and sharing your findings?  Maybe this insight could be in your snappy headline.

comment info: Hello my name is Atul Wadhwani and i'm an esl student at ccb school. The graph looks like it's  about the immigration system showing  how many people are moving from their country to other countries. The funny thing is it looks like many people are moving to United states.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, Atul.  Thank you for your response.
There are many people who are migrating from one continent to another.  I wonder how many there were in 2017.  Can you calculate the number?

But others migrate within their continent.  I wonder how many people did not leave their continent, but migrated within it.  

I wonder, which is greater in 2017 – migrating between continents or within continents?

name: Ellesa and Ava
comment info:
We noticed that there is a lot more people moving into North America than are moving out. Also, Europe and Asia have a lot of people moving within the continent.
We were curious why there were such large numbers of people migrating within Asia.
A good title would be Mass Migration: People Really Don't Like Where They Live.

name: Henry
comment info:
In this graph, I noticed how there were relatively no North Americans who migrated to other continents.

I wonder how the graph would differ if it were based off of relative frequencies, rather than frequencies. It would be interesting to see the difference that Asia has due to the large population. 

Snappy headline
2017 Migration

replies.comment info:
Henry, you bring up relative frequencies.
I wonder if you mean the proportion of migration to the continent’s population?  How could you easily find the data to calculate these proportions?  How about doing it and sharing your findings?
You are definitely onto something here.  Maybe this insight could be in your snappy headline.

@Henry,  you bring up relative frequencies.  I wonder if you mean the proportion of migration to the continent’s population?  How could you easily find the data to calculate these proportions?  How about doing it and sharing your findings?  Maybe this insight could be in your snappy headline.

comment info:

"The Great Migration 2017 Colorized"

name: Chris and Elise
comment info:
1. We noticed that most people are migrating to Europe and North America, and a lot less people migrate to Asia, Africa, Latin America, and Oceania. A lot of people migrate within the country in Europe and Asia.

2. We wonder why so many people are migrating within Europe and Asia, and why are so few people going to Oceania.

3. Migration Between Different Continents in 2017

name: Katie N
comment info:
Couple things we noticed:
- The biggest migration is from South Asia to North Asia (63.3 mil.)
- Migration from America to Latin America (1.4 mil)  is significantly less than the migration to America from Latin America (26.4 mil)
Couple things we wonder:
- Why do so many people migrate from both South Asia to North Asia and East Europe to West Europe?
Headline Idea:
- "Migration in Millions: How the World Moves"

replies.comment info:
Welcome, Katie.  I see that you focused on both migration between continents and within continents.    I wonder which is greater for the entire world – between or within continents.

Also, I see that you noted that migration within a continent went in one direction, for example, you said from Eastern Europe to Western Europe.  The map uses a directed arrow that points in one direction.  What happened to the migration in the other direction?  Could this be the net migration, for example, Eastern Europe minus Western Europe?  Or, maybe there is another explanation.  I think you are onto something.  Maybe discuss this with your class.

Finally, love your headline.  Double entendre!

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to “What’s Going On in This Graph?”. Today’s graph shows migration within and between continents for 2017. Please study the graph and, from 9 am – 2 pm E.T., give us your responses online to these three questions. (On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.) 

What do you NOTICE in this graph? 

What do you WONDER? What are you curious about that come from what you notice in the graphs?

What’s GOING ON in this graph?
Write a catchy headline that captures the graph’s main idea.  If your headline makes a claim, tell us what you noticed that supports your claim.

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order. Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with the headline.

Then, read some responses. Click on "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going. Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response. 

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

replies.name: P
replies.comment info: This graph is interesting. There seems to lots of migrations in North America than Europe/  I wonder why Mexico is nearby South American than North America.
